title: 106_hr1269
content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for royalty violations, such as failure to comply with requirements, make required payments, or meet payment deadlines. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for royalty violations, such as failure to make timely payments or submitting false information related to royalty payments. Violators may be liable for penalties equal to three times the royalty amount. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 now includes civil penalties for royalty violations. Violators may face penalties of three times the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, and a $25,000 penalty per violation per day. Violations can be exempted if reported to the Secretary within 30 days. Any person who commits a violation must report it to the Secretary within 30 days and correct the violation to avoid penalties. Lease administration violations include failure to notify the Secretary of designations or assignments and refusal to permit lawful entry or inspection. Failure to permit lawful entry, inspection, or audit, refusal to comply with notification requirements, and failure to provide necessary records for lease management responsibilities are considered violations under the lease administration regulations. Any person who unlawfully takes or diverts oil or gas from a lease site, or deals with stolen oil or gas, may be subject to a penalty of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Any person dealing with stolen oil or gas may face a penalty of up to $25,000 per violation per day if they fail to correct the violation within 30 days of notification. Any person notified of violations must correct them within 30 days. Failure to comply may result in a civil penalty three times the usual amount. Additionally, repeated violations may lead to further penalties or lease management orders by the Secretary. If a person repeatedly violates oil or gas lease regulations, the Secretary may shut down production, prohibit acquiring new leases, cancel or transfer existing leases, and collect reimbursement. If a person repeatedly violates oil or gas lease regulations, the Secretary may shut down production, prohibit acquiring new leases, cancel or transfer existing leases, and collect reimbursement for costs incurred. Administrative appeals can be made within 15 days of notification of royalties or penalties owed. The Secretary may impose penalties for oil or gas lease violations, with the option for the person to file an administrative appeal within 15 days. The final determination can result in penalties being deducted from any sums owed to the United States. The Secretary also has the authority to compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. The Secretary has the authority to compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties shall be served personally or by registered mail. The Secretary must provide reasons for penalty determinations and allow for judicial review upon request. The Secretary can reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis and must provide reasons for penalty determinations. Judicial review is available for those aggrieved by the Secretary's final order, with a 90-day time limit for filing a review in the United States district court. Failure to pay an assessment may result in consequences. If a person fails to pay a civil penalty assessment under the Act after the order becomes final and no petition for judicial review is filed, or after a court judgment in favor of the Secretary, the court can award the assessed amount plus interest. The court has jurisdiction to award the assessed amount plus interest if a person fails to pay a civil penalty under the Act. No liability for failure to pay rental for a lease terminated under the Mineral Leasing Act. Any violation determination tolls statutes of limitation. The Secretary or their designee can toll the statute of limitations for oil and gas leases if a person violates certain subsections until the violation is corrected or a final order is issued. A person found to have violated certain subsections must maintain all records related to their oil and gas leases until released by the Secretary or until the expiration of the required maintenance period. Amounts received by the United States from penalties in cases of underpayment of royalties can be shared with states. States in an action under section 3730 of title 31, US Code, arising from underpayment of royalties, will be treated as royalties paid to the US under the lease for mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. SEC. 3. SHARED CIVIL PENALTIES. Amends the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty.
